natural problem: Everyone in a class of 30 students takes math and history.  Seven students received an A in history and 13 received an A in math, including four that received an A in both courses. How many students did not receive an A in any of these two courses?
natural solution: Adding the numbers of students with A's in history and math gives $7+13 = 20$. But this counts the 4 kids who got A's in both twice, so there are $20-4=16$ different students total who received an A in at least one of the courses.
That leaves $30-16=\boxed{14}$ who didn't get an A in either.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_students a_in_history a_in_math a_in_both :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 30"
and h1 : "a_in_history = 7"
and h2 : "a_in_math = 13"
and h3 : "a_in_both = 4"
shows  "total_students - a_in_history - a_in_math + a_in_both = 14"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Everyone in a class of 30 students takes math and history.  Seven students received an A in history and 13 received an A in math, including four that received an A in both courses. How many students did not receive an A in any of these two courses? The final Answer is 14
 ### Proof
 Adding the numbers of students with A's in history and math gives $7+13 = 20$. But this counts the 4 kids who got A's in both twice, so there are $20-4=16$ different students total who received an A in at least one of the courses.
 That leaves $30-16=\boxed{14}$ who didn't get an A in either.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_students a_in_history a_in_math a_in_both :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 30"
and h1 : "a_in_history = 7"
and h2 : "a_in_math = 13"
and h3 : "a_in_both = 4"
shows  "total_students - a_in_history - a_in_math + a_in_both = 14"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: "In a class of 30 students, 7 students take history, 13 students take math, and 4 students take both history and math. How many students are taking neither history nor math? The final answer is 14."

a_1.formal problem:

assumes h0 : "total_students = 30"
and h1 : "students_with_A_in_math = 13"
and h2 : "students_with_A_in_history = 7"
and h3 : "students_with_A_in_both = 4"
shows  "total_students - (students_with_A_in_math + students_with_A_in_history - students_with_A_in_both) = 14"
a_1.formal solution:

 Adding the numbers of students with A's in history and math gives $7+13 = 20$. But this counts the 4 kids who got A's in both twice, so there are $20-4=16$ different students total who received an A in at least one of the courses.
 That leaves $30-16=\boxed{14}$ who didn't get an A in either.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_students students_with_A_in_math students_with_A_in_history students_with_A_in_both :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 30"
and h1 : "students_with_A_in_math = 13"
and h2 : "students_with_A_in_history = 7"
and h3 : "students_with_A_in_both = 4"

a_2.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes students :: nat
assumes h0 : "students = 30"
and h1 : "let A_Math = 13; A_History = 7; A_Both = 4 in A_Math + A_History - A_Both = 16"
shows  "students - 16 = 14"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Everyone in a class of 30 students takes math and history.  Seven students received an A in history and 13 received an A in math, including four that received an A in both courses. How many students did not receive an A in any of these two courses? The final Answer is 14

 Adding the numbers of students with A's in history and math gives $7+13 = 20$. But this counts the 4 kids who got A's in both twice, so there are $20-4=16$ different students total who received an A in at least one of the courses.
 That leaves $30-16=\boxed{14}$ who didn't get an A in either.
 *)

theorem 
fixes students :: nat
assumes h0 : "students = 30"
and h1 : "let A_Math = 13; A_History = 7; A_Both = 4 in A_Math + A_History - A_Both = 16"
shows  "students - 16 = 14"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a class of 30 students, 13 students are taking math, 7 students are taking history, and 4 students are taking both math and history. How many students are not taking either math or history? The final answer is 14.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_students :: int and total_math :: int and total_history :: int and both_courses :: int
assumes h0 : "total_students = 30"
and h1 : "total_math = 13"
and h2 : "total_history = 7"
and h3 : "both_courses = 4"
shows  "total_students - total_math - total_history + both_courses = 14"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Everyone in a class of 30 students takes math and history.  Seven students received an A in history and 13 received an A in math, including four that received an A in both courses. How many students did not receive an A in any of these two courses? The final Answer is 14

and h2 : "total_history = 7"

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: "nat set" and math :: "nat set" and history :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card students = 30"
and h1 : "card history = 7"
and h2 : "card math = 13"
and h3 : "card (history \<inter> math) = 4"
shows  "card (students - (math \<union> history)) = 14"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Everyone in a class of 30 students takes math and history.  Seven students received an A in history and 13 received an A in math, including four that received an A in both courses. How many students did not receive an A in any of these two courses? The final Answer is 14
 ### Proof
 Adding the numbers of students with A's in history and math gives $7+13 = 20$. But this counts the 4 kids who got A's in both twice, so there are $20-4=16$ different students total who received an A in at least one of the courses.
 That leaves $30-16=\boxed{14}$ who didn't get an A in either.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: "nat set" and math :: "nat set" and history :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card students = 30"
and h1 : "card history = 7"
and h2 : "card math = 13"
and h3 : "card (history \<inter> math) = 4"
shows  "card (students - (math \<union> history)) = 14"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a class of 30 students, 7 students are studying history and 13 students are studying math. If 4 students are studying both history and math, how many students are not studying either history or math? The final answer is 14.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A_History A_Math :: "nat set"
and A_Both A_Neither :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A_History \<union> A_Math = A_Both \<union> A_Neither"
and h1 : "card A_History = 7"
and h2 : "card A_Math = 13"
and h3 : "card A_Both = 4"
and h4 : "card (A_History \<union> A_Math \<union> A_Both \<union> A_Neither) = 30"
shows  "card A_Neither = 14"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Everyone in a class of 30 students takes math and history.  Seven students received an A in history and 13 received an A in math, including four that received an A in both courses. How many students did not receive an A in any of these two courses? The final Answer is 14
 ### Proof
 Adding the numbers of students with A's in history and math gives $7+13 = 20$. But this counts the 4 kids who got A's in both twice, so there are $20-4=16$ different students total who received an A in at least one of the courses.
 That leaves $30-16=\boxed{14}$ who didn't get an A in either.
 *)

theorem
fixes A_History A_Math :: "nat set"
and A_Both A_Neither :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A_History \<union> A_Math = A_Both \<union> A_Neither"
and h1 : "card A_History = 7"
and h2 : "card A_Math = 13"
and h3 : "card A_Both = 4"
and h4 : "card (A_History \<union> A_Math \<union> A_Both \<union> A_Neither) = 30"
shows  "card A_Neither = 14"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a class of 30 students, 7 are studying History, 13 are studying Math, and 4 are studying both. How many students are not studying either History or Math? The answer is 14.
